questions.text: Physiological hyperplasia and hypertrophy are seen simultaneously in? Uterus in pregnancy Skeletal muscle in athletes Breast at puberty Left ventricle of heart in hypertensive patients
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Both 1 and 3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option 1 : During pregnancy, the uterus undergoes both hyperplasia (increased number of cells) and hypertrophy (increase in the size of existing cells) as a physiological response to accommodate and support the developing fetus . This dual increase in size and number of cells allows the uterus to significantly expand during pregnancy .
  • • Option 1
  • • pregnancy,
  • • both hyperplasia (increased number of cells) and hypertrophy (increase in the size of existing cells)
  • • accommodate and support the developing fetus
  • • allows the uterus
  • • expand during pregnancy
  • • Option 2: Athletes who undergo rigorous training often experience skeletal muscle hypertrophy , which is the increase in the size of muscle cells , but not typically hyperplasia , which would be an increase in the number of muscle cells. Muscle growth in athletes is usually attributed to hypertrophy from repetitive use and strain .
  • • Option 2:
  • • experience skeletal muscle hypertrophy
  • • increase in the size of muscle cells
  • • not typically hyperplasia
  • • Muscle growth
  • • hypertrophy from repetitive use and strain
  • • Option 3: During puberty , the female breast displays both hyperplasia , with the proliferation of glandular epithelium, and hypertrophy , with the enlargement of the glandular epithelial cells . This dual change is stimulated by hormonal influences and is a natural part of sexual maturation .
  • • Option 3:
  • • During puberty
  • • both hyperplasia
  • • proliferation of glandular epithelium,
  • • hypertrophy
  • • enlargement of the glandular epithelial cells
  • • by hormonal influences
  • • sexual maturation
  • • Option 4: In hypertensive patients , the left ventricle may undergo hypertrophy due to increased resistance that the heart has to pump against . This is not a physiological but rather a pathological response and typically does not involve hyperplasia , which would be characterized by an increased number of cardiac muscle cells.
  • • Option 4:
  • • In hypertensive patients
  • • left ventricle
  • • hypertrophy due to increased resistance
  • • pump against
  • • pathological response
  • • does not involve hyperplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the uterus during pregnancy and the breast at puberty , physiological changes involve both hyperplasia ( increase in the number of cells) and hypertrophy (increase in the size of cells). These changes are driven by hormonal influences that are part of natural growth and development processes .
  • ➤ In the uterus during pregnancy
  • ➤ the breast at puberty
  • ➤ hyperplasia (
  • ➤ hypertrophy
  • ➤ driven by hormonal influences

questions.text: A smoker was found to have replacement of ciliated columnar epithelium in his respiratory tract to squamous epithelium. Which of the following is the mechanism involved in the observed change?

options.label: A
options.text: Reprogramming of local tissue stem cells

options.label: C
options.text: Growth factor driven proliferation of mature cells

questions.correct_answer: A. Reprogramming of local tissue stem cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reprogramming of local tissue stem cells

Explanation:

  • • cells reduce in size
  • • loss of cell substance
  • • disuse, decreased blood supply, malnutrition, or denervation
  • • Option C. Growth factor-driven proliferation refers to the increase in cell number due to stimulation by growth factors. This is the underlying mechanism of hyperplasia, a condition characterized by an increased number of cells in a tissue or organ, often as a response to a stimulus .
  • • Option C. Growth factor-driven proliferation refers to the increase in cell
  • • mechanism of hyperplasia,
  • • increased number of cells in a tissue or organ,
  • • response to a stimulus
  • • Option D. Increased cellular protein production is typically observed in hypertrophy , where cells increase in size. This often occurs in response to increased demand or hormonal stimulation , such as in muscle cells after extensive exercise or in the myocardium in response to hypertension .
  • • Option D. Increased cellular protein production
  • • hypertrophy
  • • increased demand or hormonal stimulation
  • • muscle cells after extensive exercise
  • • myocardium in response to hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The correct mechanism involved in the change from ciliated columnar epithelium to squamous epithelium in the respiratory tract of a smoker is, reprogramming of local tissue stem cells . Metaplasia occurs due to the reprogramming of stem cells in the tissue to produce a cell type better suited to withstand the stress , in this case, the chronic irritation from smoking .

questions.text: With regards to dysplasia, which of the following features is CORRECT?

options.label: B
options.text: It is characterized by cellular pleomorphism

options.label: C
options.text: It is not associated with architectural abnormalities

options.label: D
options.text: It is a feature of mesenchymal cells

questions.correct_answer: B. It is characterized by cellular pleomorphism
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is characterized by cellular pleomorphism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. It inevitably progresses to cancer: This is incorrect. Dysplasia refers to disordered cell growth and can be a precursor to cancer but does not inevitably progress to cancer. Some forms of dysplasia may regress or remain stable without progressing to malignancy.
  • • Option A. It inevitably progresses to cancer: This is incorrect.
  • • Dysplasia
  • • disordered cell growth
  • • but does not inevitably progress to cancer.
  • • Option C. It is not associated with architectural abnormalities: This statement is false . Dysplasia is often associated with a loss of normal tissue architecture , including the uniformity and architectural orientation of cells .
  • • Option C. It is not associated with architectural abnormalities: This statement is false
  • • associated with a loss of normal tissue architecture
  • • uniformity and architectural orientation of cells
  • • Option D. It is a feature of mesenchymal cells: Incorrect. Dysplasia is typically a feature of epithelial cells , not mesenchymal cells. Mesenchymal cells can undergo changes that may be equivalent to dysplasia , such as in fibroblastic proliferations, but the term dysplasia is usually used with epithelial pathology .
  • • Option D.
  • • It is a feature of mesenchymal cells:
  • • Incorrect. Dysplasia
  • • epithelial cells
  • • Mesenchymal cells
  • • equivalent to dysplasia
  • • dysplasia is usually used with epithelial pathology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dysplasia is characterized by cellular pleomorphism, which refers to variations in size and shape among cells , commonly observed in epithelial tissues where disordered growth is present.
  • ➤ Dysplasia
  • ➤ cellular pleomorphism,
  • ➤ variations in size and shape among cells
  • ➤ epithelial tissues
  • ➤ disordered growth

  • • Option B. Reducing stress:
  • • health benefits and can improve quality of life
  • • extending lifespan is complex and not as well-established

  • • obesity and associated health problems that may shorten life expectancy.

  • • lungs related to smoking or pollution

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with a painful and tender nodule on her shin. She reports a history of tuberculosis and was treated successfully. A biopsy of the lesion shows a granulomatous inflammation with giant cells. What type of giant cells is most likely present in her lesion?

  • • single macrophage,
  • • nuclei are haphazardly arranged within the cell
  • • Option C. Touton giant cells are typically found in fat necrosis and some tumors . They have a ring of nuclei surrounded by foamy cytoplasm and are not typically associated with granulomatous inflammation from tuberculosis.

  • • ring of nuclei surrounded by foamy cytoplasm
  • • Option D . Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells are multinucleated giant cells found in the hyperplastic lymphoid tissue , commonly associated with measles and other viral infections , not tuberculosis.
  • • Option D
  • • . Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells
  • • multinucleated giant cells
  • • hyperplastic lymphoid tissue
  • • measles and other viral infections

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents with a sudden onset of severe pain, redness, and swelling in the big toe. His serum uric acid levels are elevated. They recognize structurally conserved molecules derived from microbes and are important in the initial immune response, not specifically in the recognition of uric acid crystals associated with gout.

questions.text: In a patient with a suspected immune deficiency, various components of the immune system are being assessed to identify the potential defect. Which of the following immune components is primarily associated with adaptive immunity rather than innate immunity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) B lymphocytes

  • • antimicrobial peptides
  • • Paneth cells in the intestines
  • • innate immune
  • • microbes and contribute to the innate defense of mucosal surfaces.
  • • Option C: Delta Gamma T Lymphocytes: Delta gamma T cells (γδ T cells) are a subset of T cells that have T cell receptors different from the classic αβ T cell receptors. These cells can respond to certain antigens without the need for antigen processing and presentation by MHC molecules , bridging innate and adaptive immunity . They are often considered a part of the innate immune system due to their rapid response and lack of requirement for specific antigen presentation.
  • • Option C: Delta Gamma T Lymphocytes:
  • • subset of T cells
  • • αβ T cell receptors.
  • • without
  • • antigen processing and presentation by MHC molecules
  • • innate and adaptive immunity
  • • rapid response and lack of requirement for specific antigen presentation.
  • • Option D: Lectin Pathway: The lectin pathway is part of the complement system , which is a key component of the innate immune system. It involves the binding of mannose-binding lectin to pathogens , leading to their opsonization and subsequent phagocytosis or lysis .

  • • mannose-binding lectin to pathogens
  • • opsonization and subsequent phagocytosis or lysis

questions.text: During a hospital outbreak of a severe systemic inflammatory response syndrome, an infectious disease consultant suggests the possibility of superantigen involvement. Which of the following mechanisms best l the action of bacterial superantigens in the context of this condition?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: B. Binds to the beta chain of TCR and MHC class II molecules of APC stimulating T cell activation
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Binds to the beta chain of TCR and MHC class II molecules of APC stimulating T cell activation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Binds to B7 and CD28 co-stimulatory molecules: These molecules are involved in the second signal required for T cell activation. However, superantigens do not typically bind to these molecules directly.
  • • Option A: Binds to B7 and CD28 co-stimulatory molecules:
  • • second signal required for T cell activation.
  • • Option C: Binds to the CD4+ molecule causing T cell activation: While CD4+ is a co-receptor for TCRs on helper T cells, superantigens do not primarily function by binding to CD4+ molecules. They act more broadly to cross-link TCRs and MHC class II molecules.
  • • Option C: Binds to the CD4+ molecule causing T cell activation:
  • • co-receptor for TCRs on helper T cells, superantigens
  • • not
  • • binding to CD4+ molecules.
  • • cross-link TCRs and MHC class II molecules.
  • • Option D: Is presented by macrophages to a larger-than-normal number of T helper CD4+ lymphocytes: Superantigens do not get presented in the conventional sense as peptides by APCs . Instead, they interact with TCRs and MHC class II molecules to non-specifically activate a large number of T cells.
  • • Option D: Is presented by macrophages to a larger-than-normal number of T helper CD4+ lymphocytes:
  • • peptides by APCs
  • • TCRs and MHC class II molecules to non-specifically
  • • T cells.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Superantigens are bacterial products that can cause a massive T cell response by binding to the beta chain of TCRs and MHC class II molecules on APCs , leading to the non-specific activation of T cells. Some examples include toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins (SPE), Staphylococcal enterotoxins (SE), and enterotoxogenic E. coli (ETEC) enterotoxin.
  • ➤ Superantigens

questions.text: In a clinical scenario where a male child presents with recurrent infections, eczema, and thrombocytopenia, which of the following genetic evaluations is most appropriate to confirm the suspected diagnosis?

  • • Reduced or absent adenosine deaminase activity
  • • severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID),
  • • recurrent infections
  • • does not
  • • eczema or thrombocytopenia

These conditions can present with rash and are associated with immune dysregulation , but they do not typically cause thrombocytopenia as a primary manifestation.

  • • autoimmune conditions, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE),
  • • rash and are associated with immune dysregulation

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with no prior allergies receives penicillin for a bacterial infection. Two days later, he presents with wheezing and laboratory tests showing hemolysis with a positive direct Coombs test. Which hypersensitivity reaction is most likely responsible for this patient's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type II

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A: Type I Hypersensitivity: Type I hypersensitivity reactions are immediate reactions mediated by IgE antibodies. Typical manifestations include urticaria, angioedema, asthma, and anaphylaxis, usually occurring within minutes to hours after exposure to the allergen.
  • • Option A: Type I Hypersensitivity:
  • • immediate reactions mediated by IgE antibodies.
  • • urticaria, angioedema, asthma, and anaphylaxis,
  • • minutes to hours
  • • allergen.
  • • Option C: Type III Hypersensitivity: Type III hypersensitivity reactions are immune complex-mediated . They occur when antigens and IgG antibodies form immune complexes that deposit in various tissues, causing inflammation and tissue damage, such as in s erum sickness or certain glomerulonephritides.
  • • Option C: Type III Hypersensitivity:
  • • immune complex-mediated
  • • antigens and IgG antibodies form immune complexes
  • • erum sickness or certain glomerulonephritides.
  • • Option D: Type IV Hypersensitivity: Type IV hypersensitivity reactions are delayed-type reactions mediated by T cells . Symptoms typically appear 48-72 hours after exposure to the antigen , as seen in contact dermatitis or a positive tuberculosis skin test .
  • • Option D: Type IV Hypersensitivity:
  • • delayed-type reactions mediated by T cells
  • • 48-72 hours after exposure to the antigen
  • • contact dermatitis or a positive tuberculosis skin test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patient's hemolysis following penicillin administration suggests a type II hypersensitivity reaction, where the drug acts as a hapten, binding to red blood cell membranes and inducing an antibody response against the drug-protein complex .
  • ➤ hemolysis following penicillin
  • ➤ type II hypersensitivity reaction,

  • ➤ inducing an antibody response against the drug-protein complex

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with a history of itching, hives, and difficulty breathing after eating a peanut butter sandwich. On examination, she has wheezing and diffuse urticaria. Which of the following hypersensitivity reactions is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Type I hypersensitivity reaction

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B: Type II Hypersensitivity Reaction: Type II hypersensitivity is antibody-mediated and usually targets cellular antigens, leading to conditions like hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and certain drug reactions. It is not associated with allergies to foods.

  • • antibody-mediated
  • • targets cellular antigens,
  • • hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and certain drug reactions.
  • • not
  • • allergies to foods.
  • • Option C: Type III Hypersensitivity Reaction: Type III hypersensitivity involves immune complex deposition and is implicated in conditions like serum sickness and certain glomerulonephritides. It is not typically involved in reactions to foods.
  • • Option C: Type III Hypersensitivity Reaction:
  • • immune complex deposition
  • • serum sickness and certain glomerulonephritides.
  • • Option D: Type IV Hypersensitivity Reaction: Type IV hypersensitivity, or delayed-type hypersensitivity , is T cell-mediated and occurs 48–72 hours after exposure to an antigen , as seen in contact dermatitis or a positive tuberculosis skin test . It does not cause immediate symptoms like those seen in anaphylaxis.
  • • Option D: Type IV Hypersensitivity Reaction:
  • • delayed-type hypersensitivity
  • • T cell-mediated and occurs 48–72 hours after exposure to an antigen
  • • dermatitis or a positive tuberculosis skin test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The patient's symptoms of itching, hives, and difficulty breathing immediately following ingestion of a known allergen are indicative of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction . This reaction is mediated by IgE antibodies specific to the allergen , leading to mast cell degranulation and the release of histamine and other mediators .
  • ➤ itching, hives, and difficulty breathing immediately following ingestion of a known allergen are indicative of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction
  • ➤ IgE antibodies specific to the allergen
  • ➤ cell degranulation and the release of histamine and other mediators

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a painless lesion on her ear lobe (shown in the image) after getting her ears pierced 3 months ago. Which of the following best explains the pathogenesis of this lesion?

questions.text: A patient presents with a growth suspected to be related to a low risk HPV subtypes. Which of the following is most likely responsible with HPV strains 6 and 11?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Laryngeal papillomatosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cervical carcinoma is typically caused by high-risk HPV strains such as HPV-16 and HPV-18 , not the low-risk strains that cause laryngeal papillomatosis .
  • • Option A.
  • • Cervical carcinoma
  • • high-risk HPV strains
  • • HPV-16 and HPV-18
  • • not the low-risk strains
  • • laryngeal papillomatosis
  • • Option B. Oral carcinoma can also be caused by high-risk HPV strains , particularly HPV-16 , which is associated with oropharyngeal cancers .
  • • Option B.
  • • Oral carcinoma
  • • high-risk HPV strains
  • • HPV-16
  • • oropharyngeal cancers
  • • Option D. Anorectal carcinoma is associated with high-risk HPV strains , similar to cervical and oral carcinomas .
  • • Option D.
  • • Anorectal carcinoma
  • • high-risk HPV strains
  • • cervical and oral carcinomas

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Low-risk HPV strains , such as HPV-6 and HPV-11, are associated with benign conditions such as laryngeal papillomatosis, while high-risk HPV strains are associated with malignancies like cervical, oral, and anorectal carcinoma.
  • ➤ Low-risk HPV strains
  • ➤ HPV-6 and HPV-11,
  • ➤ benign conditions such as laryngeal papillomatosis,
  • ➤ high-risk HPV strains
  • ➤ cervical, oral, and anorectal carcinoma.

questions.text: 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with breast cancer, and her tumor cells demonstrate overexpression of the HER2/neu proto-oncogene. What is the primary mechanism by which HER2/neu contributes to the pathophysiology of her cancer?
questions.correct_answer: D. Activation of cell signaling pathways
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Activation of cell signaling pathways

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Inhibition of cell proliferation is not associated with HER2/neu overexpression; instead, HER2/neu leads to increased cell proliferation .
  • • Option A.
  • • Inhibition of cell proliferation
  • • not
  • • HER2/neu overexpression;
  • • HER2/neu
  • • increased cell proliferation
  • • Option B. Promotion of apoptosis is not a mechanism of HER2/neu action . In contrast, HER2/neu overexpression tends to confer resistance to apoptotic signals .
  • • Option B.
  • • Promotion of apoptosis
  • • not
  • • HER2/neu action
  • • HER2/neu overexpression
  • • resistance to apoptotic signals
  • • Option C. While HER2/neu overexpression can have d ownstream effects that might indirectly promote angiogenesis , this is not the primary action of the proto-oncogene.
  • • Option C.
  • • HER2/neu
  • • ownstream effects
  • • indirectly promote angiogenesis
  • • not the primary action of the proto-oncogene.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Overexpression of the HER2/neu proto-oncogene in breast cancer leads to the activation of cell signaling pathways that promote cell proliferation and survival. This overexpression is associated with a more aggressive disease phenotype and a poorer prognosis . Targeted therapies against HER2/neu can be effective in treating tumors with this over-expression .

  • ➤ cell signaling pathways
